message: It was an honor to once again take the oath of office. I am thankful and humbled to continue representing  the residents of Southwest Washington in the U.S. Congress.

We are less than a week into 2017 and federal agencies have wasted no time releasing a stack of new regulations! Federal regulations often are prohibitively costly and unnecessary, and they harm local job creators and communities. Yesterday, Congress passed the REINS Act requiring federal government agencies to submit major regulations to Congress for approval.

I learned of Lewis County veteran John Weston’s tragic death after a delay in care. I am asking the VA secretary for an internal investigation to see what happened and make sure it doesn’t happen to other veterans.

Today is Law Enforcement Appreciation Day, and we thank the brave men and women serving in law enforcement in Southwest Washington, and throughout our nation. I will continue to support our officers who put themselves in harm’s way for the safety of our communities.

It’s vital that we move forward with replacing the Affordable Care Act in a manner that doesn't cause additional disruption to those families who have already endured higher costs and the loss of their doctors and plans since the ACA was forced upon them.  As such, any action to repeal on the U.S. House floor should be accompanied by a simultaneous and immediate strategy for replacing it. Read my letter from today to Speaker Paul Ryan about making health care better in Southwest Washington.

This week, I introduced a bill that would permanently extend a decades-long fishery agreement to support the jobs within Washington state’s Dungeness crab industry. Reauthorizing the agreement between Washington, Oregon and California will ensure managers use state coordination to appropriately manage the West Coast crab fishery in federal waters. The agreement is vital for Washington’s economy, as our crab industry brings $61 million into the state’s economy annually and provides more than 60,000 maritime jobs.

Next week, I will have the honor of recognizing a true American hero. Craig Robinson assisted in caring for critically wounded Marines in the immediate aftermath of the 1983 Marine barracks bombing in Beirut, going beyond the call of duty on his first day in the Navy. His courage and strength are trademarks of all our military men and women, and I'm proud to share our gratitude and appreciation with him. If you're near Chehalis, I hope you will join us for this public ceremony next Monday.

It was a great honor to be part of veteran Craig Robinson’s pinning ceremony earlier this week. Please check out this article to read more about his brave and sacrificial service to our county and fellow service members right after the bombing of the Marine barracks in Beirut.

Please see a letter that my Washington GOPcolleagues and I sent to Governor Jay Inslee and Insurance Commissioner Mike Kreidler responding to their correspondence concerninghealth care. While we agree that all Washington state residents deserve access to quality health care, there are too many failures in the Affordable Care Act to achieve that goal.  We are working to do better.
Just kicked off the Congressional Maternity Care Caucus for 2017 with my colleague, Rep. Lucille Roybal-Allard. 2016 was great year with new initiatives & bills passed to help moms & babies!

I’m pleased that my colleagues in the House passed the permanent extension of the tri-state agreement that is imperative for the future success of the West Coast Dungeness crab fishery, bringing certainty to an industry that helps support 60,000 maritime jobs in Washington state.
Click here to read Pennie Saum’s tragic story and how it inspired Congresswoman Suzan DelBenee and me to develop a bill to help survivors of sexual assault seek justice.

The IRS says Americans shouldn’t have a “reasonable expectation of privacy” in emails and other online communication.  That’s wrong, and unconstitutional. Yesterday, the U.S. House passed bipartisan legislation that would extend the same privacy protections to electronic communications that exist for hard mail and other personal, paper documents.  Under this bipartisan bill, a government agency would not be able to access a U.S. citizen’s emails without a court-ordered search warrant.

There is currently a loophole that shields convicted child abusers from paying the restitution they owe if their income comes from military retirement pay. I joined with Congresswoman Suzan DelBene to close this loophole and bring justice to the survivors of these horrible acts. Read more.

Meeting with crab fishermen about protecting coastal jobs and their industry. It will help if we have the resources to complete dredging and get my Dungeness crab fisheries management bill across the finish line and signed into law.

Many people are struggling with mental health and substance abuse in our communities, and because of the shortage of inpatient beds it can be weeks or months before individuals can receive treatment. I just introduced a bipartisan bill with Rep. Derek Kilmer that will be a benefit to many individuals and families struggling with mental health disorders. Too often, hospitals and law enforcement are having to overcommit resources and are simply ill-equipped to try and assist those individuals in a mental health crisis.  Our effort will provide relief and strengthen our communities without putting any additional burdens on taxpayers.

Whenever I attend a presidential speech to Congress, I look first for areas of common ground where we can work together to improve conditions for the people I serve in Southwest Washington.  Tonight was no exception and I look forward to working with President Trump to truly improve health care in this country for everyone – including protecting access for those who currently have coverage, and those with pre-existing conditions.  Where Obamacare has failed, we need health care solutions that will actually make quality health care affordable and accessible for everyone.  I was also encouraged by the president's championing of efforts to make the workplace better for parents and to protect good jobs and create better-paying ones by strengthening opportunities for small businesses.  And I stand ready to partner with him on rebuilding our infrastructure to get our economy moving again. After tonight's speech, I see a number of areas we can cooperate and make life better for Southwest Washington residents, and I’m ready to get to work.

My new bipartisan legislation introduced today will allow states to address preventable maternal deaths. The United States is ranked 50th globally for its maternal mortality rate, which is why The Preventing Maternal Deaths Act is critical #Act2SaveMoms

Kidneys are one of the several organs that can be given by a living donors. There are over 100,000 people currently waiting for kidney transplants in the United States.  Today I spoke at a press conference about the need for the Living Donor Protection Act that gives living donors access to FMLA for recovery from a transplant surgery. It also makes sure these life-giving donors are not penalized by insurance companies for volunteering to donate.

Karcher, an employer in Camas, showed me some of the equipment they manufacture that’s vital to protecting our waterways from invasive species like Quagga and Zebra mussels.   Contamination would wreak havoc on the Columbia River system, and be a devastating blow to our economy and environment. Read more about my efforts to prevent the spread of invasive species in the Northwest.
It was great to hear from Jennifer Garner, a fellow mom, about the importance of early education and childhood development.

Today, I successfully amended a bill to address the high staff turnover at the VA that leads to long wait times for veterans. My amendment strengthens anonymity protections for VA employees who fill out surveys upon their departures. Only if VA providers are telling the honest truth about what they saw, heard and experienced in the workplace can the VA fix the problems that plague its facilities. It also requires this exit survey data to be more localized so that the agency can better solve region-specific problems.

Today the U.S. House of Representatives adopted my amendment and passed The Small Business Health Fairness Act, a bill to protect health care for 400,000 Washingtonians who receive health care through Association Health Plans. This important solution puts small businesses on an equal playing field with those bigger employers in their efforts to attract and retain employees by offering quality, affordable health care. It also helps eliminate the tremendous uncertainty individuals, families and small businesses face when their health care plans are repeatedly threatened by state officials with other agendas.

I remain steadfast in my commitment to repeal and replace Obamacare with health care solutions that better serve all residents of Southwest Washington. But we can do better than the current House replacement plan, and I cannot support it in its current form.  While I appreciate this week's effort by Speaker Ryan and his leadership team to better protect older Americans from health care cost increases, the difficulties this bill would create for millions of children were left unaddressed.  I’m disappointed that it appears my amendment to strengthen the Medicaid safety net for the kids who depend on it for their health care will not be considered.  Protecting vulnerable children is a core purpose of the Medicaid program and when the program fails to do so, it fails entirely.   I will not vote to let those kids fall through the cracks.  Southwest Washington residents also deserve a greater commitment to lowering health costs so that out-of-pocket expenses, premiums and taxes are taking up less of their monthly paychecks.  Congress should more purposefully move ahead with free market reforms that increase competition between insurance providers and drive down premiums and deductibles.  Obamacare also levied numerous taxes on hardworking Americans, and in our effort to pull back this harmful law we should more quickly repeal them.  In the final analysis, this bill falls short.  We can't give up on replacing Obamacare with a solution that provides affordable, high-quality health care to all Americans.  I will remain active and engaged at every step until Congress gets this right.

Empowering students with quality education is so important to their success, and we should identify and eliminate obstacles to achieving that goal. Unfortunately, Washington state has the most public school districts that face chronic absenteeism in the U.S. I’m pleased to have introduced a solution today that will empower educators at the local level with tools and support to address factors that are leading to kids in Southwest Washington missing school.

Today the Tsunami Warning, Education, and Research Act passed the U.S. House and is headed to the president to be signed. When it comes to our coastal communities up and down the Washington and Oregon coast, preparedness for seismic and storm events is paramount. I’m pleased to partner with Congresswoman Bonamici on this solution, which will help make citizens safer and could save lives in the event of tsunami by improving the tsunami warning system’s forecasts of tsunami arrival and damage estimates.   The bill will strengthen the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s hazard mitigation program through additional technical and financial assistance to communities.  It also establishes a working group to provide advice about tsunami science and technology and supports development of community-based outreach and education programs.

Earlier this afternoon I received a classified briefing from General Joe Dunford, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. A targeted strike against the airfield used by Assad to launch an abhorrent and illegal chemical weapons attack on his own people appears to have been an appropriate response.  If President Trump has any more plans for military action against Syria he needs to bring them before Congress.

I’m inviting Southwest Washington residents to join me for a live telephone town hall, April 13th, from 6:00pm-7:30pm. Telephone town halls are a great way for folks from rural farm land and urban centers to all join me for a live, back-and-forth conversation from the convenience of their kitchen tables. I look forward to updating residents on my efforts to improve health care, create jobs, improve education and solve problems back in Congress, and take questions and ideas on any issues that matter to them. I’ve held nearly 70 town halls, public hearings, community coffee meetings and telephone town halls all across Southwest Washington – and I’ll continue to utilize every method there is that fosters productive, civil dialogue with residents from all political viewpoints. There is a lot of interest in what’s happening in Washington, D.C. right now, and there’s no way to communicate live with as many people at once as a telephone town hall.  Southwest Washington residents can sign up to join the event by visiting my website and entering their contact information or by calling my office at 360-695-6292. Southwest Washington residents can also call in to join the telephone town hall at any point during the event by calling 1-877-229-8493 and using the passcode 116365.

Our community prioritizes protecting salmon and steelhead in the Columbia River because they are central to our way of life in the Pacific Northwest. I just joined Congressman Kurt Schrader to introduce The Endangered Salmon and Fisheries Predation Prevention Act because sea lion predation is posing a serious threat to our salmon populations, impacting our efforts to ensure their survival. With this solution, we have to tools to better protect the salmon so vital to our recreational, cultural and economic interests.
Join my live tele town hall tonight at 6pm by calling 1-877-229-8493 and using the passcode 116365 at any point during the event. You can also listen to a live stream of the event through this link.

Touring the Clark County Jail this morning was eye-opening. I saw first-hand the acute need to provide more facilities that can help those suffering from psychiatric disorders and substance abuse addictions. It was helpful for me to hear from the Clark County sheriffs and to better understand the challenges that come from limited resources to assist those with mental illness and opioid addiction. I'm eager to get my bipartisan bill signed into law, which would help communities build additional psychiatric and substance abuse treatment facilities - helping more individuals get the assistance they need, and taking pressure off of law enforcement and jails.

Those who have served our country deserve the best medical care. That’s what they were promised and that is what they have earned. Yet I hear from veteran after veteran who has to wait too long to see a doctor or specialist. This is not a simple fix, but one factor that negatively affects the quality of medical care veterans receive is high staff turnover. To find out  more about the seriousness of this issue and my legislative approach to help our veterans in Southwest Washington, read my column in the Goldendale Sentinel.

We need more resources to address mental health challenges in our community. Right now, much of the burden falls on law enforcement and the criminal justice system, like Clark County Jail. Read more about my tour of the Clark County Jail and bipartisan solution to this challenge:

Do you have unused or expired prescription medicine in your home? You can turn them in tomorrow at collection sites in Vancouver, Battle Ground, and Stevenson. Unused medicines can  increase opportunities for drug abuse and can end up in drinking water if they are flushed down the toilet or put in the trash.

Congratulations to the Evergreen and Ridgefield and Battle Ground School Districts for having schools ranked in the top 55 in Washington State!  https://www.usnews.com/education/best-high-schools/washington/rankings

I just joined my Democrat and Republican colleagues in introducing legislation to reauthorize the Secure Rural Schools program. The Secure Rural Schools program is currently the only lifeline for many formerly timber-dependent communities in Southwest Washington to keep schools, emergency services and roads operating.

I’m inviting Southwest Washington residents to join me for a live telephone town hall, May 9th at 6:00pm.  Residents can also call in to join the telephone town hall at any point during the event by calling 1-877-229-8493 and using the passcode 116365. Visit my website or call my office at 360-695-6292 for more information.
Today I applaud all the amazing teachers in SW Washington! Your hard work and selfless dedication doesn’t go unnoticed. THANK YOU! #NationalTeachersDay

I’m hosting a live telephone town hall @ 6:00pm tonight and I’d love for residents of SW Washington to join. If you’d like to participate, please visit jhb.house.gov for call-in info. Talk to you soon!
Thousands of health care professionals work together to provide care for our community in Southwest Washington. It was great to join Klickitat Valley Hospital to celebrate National Hospital Week!

Pacific County Veterans: there is still time to visit the VA Mobile Medical Unit this week!   Location: American Legion 203 Duryea St. Raymond, WA 98577  MOBILE MEDICAL UNIT (MMU) HOURS OF OPERATION:  Thursday – 8:00am-12:00pm & 1:00-3:00pm  Friday – 8:00am-12:00pm  If you are a veteran who is already registered within the VA system, walk-up appointments will be available without appointment. If you wish, you can also set up an appointment by calling 1-800-329-8387 ext. 71234 and ask for the mobile medical unit in Raymond. If you are not in the VA system, you can get help with initial registration at the mobile medical unit.

It was a huge honor to receive the Champion of Change Award from the National Down Syndrome Society. I also got to meet the caring folks who started the Southwest Washington-based organization D.A.N.A. (Differently-Abled, Nationally Accepted) that strives to create a community where every child is valued and given a voice. What a fun day!

Attention Veterans: Imposter phone line attempting to access credit card information from Choice Program.   The two phone lines differ only in area code. The correct Choice Program phone line is 1-866-606-8198, while the imposter phone line is using 1-800-606-8198. The fake line does not provide information on the Choice Program or its eligibility criteria, instead it claims to offer callers a $100 rebate if they provide a credit card number.

In honor of #NationalPoliceWeek, please join me in recognizing the sacrifice and service of our state and local law enforcement officers. I look forward to supporting several bills this week aimed at honoring police officers and ensuring they have the tools they need to do their jobs well. A huge thank you to our local law enforcement heroes!

I appreciated the opportunity to talk with the National Institute of Health today in the Appropriations Committee. I was able to ask questions on two issues of concern: Ways we can prevent teen suicide and how to better treat depression during pregnancy and postpartum.

It was fun to join my friend and colleague, Rep. Derek Kilmer, at a panel today! Thank you for inviting me to participate in this meeting to discuss the critical issue of mental health care in Washington state. Our bipartisan bill addresses the need for more inpatient beds for those suffering from mental health illness and substance abuse addictions.
Happy 1st birthday, Ethan!

Wow, we sure have some talented students in Southwest Washington! Congrats to the winners of our Congressional Art Competition.  I’m proud to have Christine’s “Unity” artwork hanging in the U.S. Capitol this year.  On Friday, May 19, from 6:00-7:00pm, my office will be hosting a Congressional Art Competition Showcase at Boomerang Coffee Shop in downtown Vancouver.

Caring for our troops is one of my top priorities. It’s essential that servicemen and women struggling with mental health issues are given the support they need, an issue highlighted by this recent report.

I commend BPA for listening to and working with Southwest Washington landowners, concerned citizens, community groups and municipalities throughout this process to assess our region’s energy needs and determine the best way to meet them.   Frankly, BPA’s willingness to reverse course on the planned 500-kilovolt lattice-steel-tower transmission line that would have bisected our communities is somewhat unprecedented. It should serve as a model for other public entities who need to be willing to constantly reassess their decisions to make sure the community is at the center of them. I applaud their decision and the process they used to get to this point.   BPA has assured me that it’s committed to meeting the present and future energy needs of our region through careful planning, system changes and innovation, and I stand ready to help meet those needs however I can. BPA’s work in providing carbonless energy to meet the needs of our community is vital.

To all our law enforcement officers who put themselves in harm’s way every day to help keep us safe – thank you! I want to especially honor those who give their lives in the line of duty; in particular, Kalama Police Chief Randy Gibson who passed away earlier this year from a duty-related illness. #NationalPoliceWeek
Students discuss their art and techniques at the 2017 Congressional Art Competition Show in Vancouver.

The House passed several bills this week to protect at-risk children, such as the Put Trafficking Victims First Act. This bill directs the Attorney General to provide training to prosecutors on investigating and processing cases with a trauma-informed and victim-centered approach, and encourages states to provide appropriate services to victims of trafficking. It’s so paramount we continue to do everything in our power to combat child abuse and exploitation.
Jaime’s Statement on the President’s Proposal to Sell BPA’s Assets

I'm pleased we passed a bill today that would ensure VA facilities follow VA’s scheduling rules, and that veterans have timely access to care. And bonus: If each medical director doesn’t comply with the scheduling directive for their facility annually, they won’t receive awards or bonuses.

Revolutionary War General John Stark said: “Live free or die.” For many of our troops, death was the price of ensuring that we could be a free people. And how grateful I am to have grown up in a free country. Today, we honor all those who paid the ultimate price for our freedom by giving their lives in defense of our nation.

I want to pay special tribute to the families of our troops. You who have supported our servicemen or women – thank you! You are the ones who watched your spouse, child, sibling, or parent leave – not knowing if they would return. And on this day, we especially recognize those who never did come back – those who gave their lives fighting for our freedom. #MemorialDay

Veterans: Mark your calendar for Monday, June 5th when the Portland VA Regional Office will host a town hall and claims clinic specifically designed to make the disability claims and vocational rehab process more visible to veterans. The claims clinic will be held on June 5th from 5:00pm to 7:30pm at the VA Portland Health Care System main campus auditorium located at 3710 SW U.S. Veterans Hospital Road, Portland. The town hall will commence at 6:00pm on June 5th. For more info, check out VA Portland Health Care System’s Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/vaportland/

Vancouver School of Arts & Academics was given a huge honor by being recognized as a national arts school. They were designated a 2017-19 Exemplary School by the Arts Schools Network. Congrats, Vancouver School District!

Chehalis schools are going the extra mile to help their students attend college. Read about their challenges, & the progress they’re seeing after just a few years: http://www.seattletimes.com/education-lab/chehalis-washington-rural-semirural-school-district-college-degrees/

Working to keep energy costs down in Southwest Washington. My Pacific NW colleagues and I sent a letter today to Secretary of Energy and Director of OMB urging them not to privatize BPA’s assets. You can see the letter we sent here: https://goo.gl/M4mxN4

I am pleased that City of Vancouver’s Fire Chief Joseph Molina has been selected to serve as a member of the FEMA National Advisory Council RESPONSE Subcommittee. Chief Molina is deserving of this prestigious appointment. His knowledge of Southwest Washington issues, especially in regards to oil train safety, will be a huge asset as he serves on the federal level.

I may have come up with a different title, but here’s a nice piece from CNN. Bottom line: I’m blessed to have a great husband and family, and I’ll always fight for Southwest Washington. www.cnn.com/badasswomen

Pleased to see my bill to protect salmon and steelhead in the Columbia River will receive a congressional hearing tomorrow morning. It’ll be live-streamed here: https://naturalresources.house.gov/calendar/eventsingle.aspx?EventID=402057
At CNN's #badasswomendc launch event — I'm one, I guess. Humbled to share the stage with these remarkable, inspiring women.
NA

As long as sea lions overpopulate the Columbia River, I will continue to advocate on behalf of endangered salmon. My bipartisan bill to protect salmon & steelhead received a congressional hearing today and I appreciated the opportunity to testify. I'm glad to see this common-sense legislation moving forward.

Grateful to have Leland Bill, Chairman of the Columbia River Inter-Tribal Fish Commission and a member of the Yakama Nation Tribal Council, join me in testifying in support of my bill at today's hearing.

Thank you, Coastal Conservation Association Washington, for your strong letter of support for my bill, Endangered Salmon and Fisheries Predation Act. I appreciate your partnership in this critical issue of salmon recovery in Southwest Washington. goo.gl/YVo8gs
Proud to have the NWPCC’s support for my bill which protects the investments being made in salmon recovery on the Columbia River by ratepayers. https://goo.gl/6kNEPf

Thank you, CNN Politics and Dana Bash, for telling our story. It’s our desire that other families who are facing complex medical diagnoses or a challenging obstacle will have hope. Dan and I are so thankful for the team who have supported us every step of the way.

I am very concerned by the dwindling health care options for folks in Klickitat County. I’m supporting a bill that would provide immediate relief to those residents who will lose health insurance coverage in 2018. I also sent a letter today to WA Insurance Commissioner urging him to find an immediate solution for residents of rural counties. You can learn more about the bill and read the letter I sent here: https://herrerabeutler.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398902

I work for veterans. I take that job seriously and am always pleased to see bills come to the House floor that support our military heroes – like this VA accountability act that we passed today. America’s veterans deserve the highest quality medical care and part of that care means ensuring underperforming VA employees are held accountable. Now this bill goes to the President!

My thoughts and prayers are with Congressman Steve Scalise, Capitol Police and all others affected by this morning’s shooting. The facts are still coming in, but it sounds like there were some heroic acts of bravery. Praying for peace & healing for all.
First full committee markup — just passed our veteran-care spending bill. Increased funding for the VA & some good measures approved thinking specifically of our Southwest Washington veterans.

Women have served our country courageously and it’s high time we ensure they receive the specialized care they need, specifically, maternity and mental health care. Pleased to see several of my provisions were included in our VA funding bill and passed out of Appropriations Committee today. We also increased funding at the VA by $5.3 billion. Read more here: https://goo.gl/LY1dAe
Thank you, Disabled American Veterns, for your strong support for women veterans and these critical provisons.
To all the dads, thank you! And a special thank you to my husband, an amazing father: http://www.oregonlive.com/politics/index.ssf/2017/06/fathers_day_meet_dan_beutler_a.html

Parents – this is an awesome opportunity for your kiddos! Children enrolled in 4th grade for the 2016-17 school year are eligible for an "Every Kid in a Park" which provides free entry onto federal public lands. For more info, visit www.everykidinapark.gov

With the recent tunnel collapse at Hanford as a reminder of its importance, I was pleased to have the opportunity today to ask Energy Secretary Rick Perry for his commitment to partner together on Hanford cleanup. We must continue to ensure the federal government lives up to its obligation in cleaning up Hanford in a safe and effective manner.

Protecting the Columbia River Basin from invasive species of mussels that threaten our fisheries and hydropower infrastructure is a top priority. Today, I joined my colleagues in a bipartisan effort requesting Secretary Ryan Zinke maximize federal resources to address this issue. Read more about our efforts here: https://goo.gl/L9cXtL

It’s imperative to the future of the country that we provide students with a quality education and opportunities to succeed in our 21st Century economy. I am pleased to join my colleagues in the House today to pass the "Strengthening Career and Technical Education for the 21st Century Act" which supports state and local career and technical education programs. Proud of the hard work and dedication of the three career and technical colleges in Southwest Washington: Lower Columbia, Centralia, and Clark.
One of the fun, annual events the family gets to attend while Congress is in session voting is the White House Picnic. The cotton candy was a family favorite.

I’d love to hear from you! Residents of Southwest Washington, please join me for a live telephone town hall on Tuesday, June 27th at 5:15pm. You can sign up to receive a call to join the telephone town hall by visiting www.jhb.house.gov and entering your contact information. You can also join at any time during the event by calling 1-877-229-8493 and using the passcode 116365.
So pleased the President just signed this bill into law!

I want to honor and thank John Deeder, Evergreen Public School Superintendent, for his 48 years of service to our Southwest Washington education community. John has taken every opportunity to serve and is a shining example of what makes this expansive region feel like a tight-knit and caring community. He is an inspiration to all of us and I wish him the best in his future endeavors. http://www.columbian.com/news/2017/jun/24/evergreen-school-chief-john-deeder-retires/

Part of fixing the challenges at the VA is fully understanding its problems, which is why I secured an important provision in a law that passed last year that requires the VA to report on its hiring issues with their health care providers. We’ve learned some of the facts, and they aren’t good: It takes on average 134 days – that’s over four months – for the Veterans Health Administration to hire a healthcare provider. And 8% of the providers who made it through the credentialing phase – which means they’ve been in the VA hiring process on average 74 days – do not end up being hired by the VHA because they receive another job opportunity during this lengthy hiring process. Then, the VHA is forced to start the hiring process all over again – at the expense of agency funding and the loss of good providers.  Veterans are the ones who ultimately feel the adverse effects of the delays when they have to wait extended periods of time to receive medical attention due to the lack of providers. This is a critical issue, and I’ll stay dogged in my efforts to better understand and help tackle these problems.

Get your questions ready! I’m looking forward to hearing what issues are important to you at my tele-town hall today from 5:15pm-6:15pm. Residents of Southwest Washington, please join the event by calling 1-877-229-8493 & using passcode 116365.

Land owners, farmers, and business owners in Southwest Washington just got one step closer to an important measure of relief. Today, the Trump Administration made the decision to withdraw the Waters of the United States rule (WOTUS), which made ditches, man-made ponds, and seasonally wet areas on private property subject to additional federal control and massive costs. I have consistently opposed this sweeping expansion of federal control that would upend 42 years of Clean Water Act policy that will do very little to protect our environment, yet could do so much to hurt farmers, small business operators, and important economic activity.
Have a happy and safe 4th of July!
Happy Independence Day!

Small, independent breweries face many economic challenges amidst a booming demand from consumers. I met with several local brewers yesterday to hear how the tax and regulatory burdens negatively affect their businesses. I have worked to increase funding for hops research, expedite the backlog for processing new craft beer and wine labeling, and fight to keep the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) as a separate, independent bureau. I also cosponsored the Craft Beverage Modernization and Tax Reform Act, which seeks to provide tax relief as a way to help smaller brewers invest in their business and spur economic growth.
Really enjoyed my stop in Cowlitz County last week. A big thank you to The Daily News for having me. Great questions about health care, energy, salmon, and bipartisanship in politics:  goo.gl/BUkEXx

I’ve been passionate about seeing more folks in Southwest Washington enter the science & technology industry and it starts with receiving a great education and necessary skills training. I was proud to participate at Clark College’s STEM building ribbon-cutting ceremony last year and now I have another opportunity in Congress to cosponsor a great bill that will help close the growing gap in the tech industry between employers and qualified workers.

Small businesses like Molecular Testing Labs (MTL) in Vancouver power our economy. I had a great time touring their facility. MTL does fascinating, important work in the areas of genetics, infectious diseases, and toxicology testing. I’m glad I could assist from the federal level by expediting their application for a Veteran Owned Small Business Certification and also working with the VA to get their Federal Supply Schedule approved.

Working to restore honor to survivors of military sexual assault who have been wrongly discharged. Today, I introduced a bipartisan bill I'm proud of with Congresswoman Niki Tsongas & Senator Richard Blumenthal: goo.gl/8B2SbC

Many rape and sexual assault survivors in the military suffering from trauma have been mischaracterized and erroneously discharged, making them ineligible to receive benefits and care from the VA. My bill allows survivors to challenge the terms of their discharge and ensures they’re given a fair hearing: goo.gl/8B2SbC

Our coastal communities in Pacific County rely on a healthy fishing industry. Pleased to improve a spending bill yesterday with my colleague Rep. Derek Kilmer that helps our local fishing guides, commercial and charter fleets, resorts, and other local businesses who are impacted when a fishery disaster is declared. Read more about our effort here: https://herrerabeutler.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398929

The House took important strides today to begin restoring justice for survivors of military sexual assault. Pleased to see my amendments were included in the U.S. House defense spending bill we just passed. Among other things, I secured provisions that require military boards receive training in sexual trauma, help survivors get successful hearings, and allow service members to challenge a wrongful discharge.  Read more about it here: JHB.house.gov

Our nation’s veterans selflessly sacrificed their lives to protect our freedom, and we must keep our promise and commitment to them by providing the necessary care that they earned. I’m pleased to announce the VA’s mobile clinic will be in Raymond this week offering health care services to our veterans.   When:  Monday, July 17, 9am-3:30pm Tuesday, July 18, 8am-3:30pm Wednesday, July 19, 8am-3:30pm Thursday, July 20, 8am-3:30pm Friday, July 21, 8am-11:30am  Where: The American Legion 221 Duryea Street Raymond, WA 98577  Services include: Primary health care appointments & walk-ups, physical exams, flu shots & other immunizations, prescriptions, labs, assistance in signing up for VA benefits  If you are a veteran who is already registered within the VA system, walk-up appointments will be accepted based on availability. If you wish, you can also set up an appointment by calling 1-800-329-8387, and then dialing extension 71234 and asking for the mobile medical unit in Raymond. If you are not in the VA system, you can get help with initial registration at the mobile medical unit.

Rural communities like Toledo, Pe Ell, and Vader have been erroneously reported as “too affluent” to qualify for much-needed grant funding. After pressuring the Dept. of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) for two years, I secured a measure in a spending plan last night that will force HUD to make its data public and report margins of error. I’m not going to let up on this issue or the needs of Lewis County until we have a long-term solution. You can read more about this issue here: goo.gl/mtGAn5

Little Charlie Gard – the 11-month-old who is fighting for his life right now in Britain. I wrote an amendment that was unanimously passed in committee today that would allow Charlie and his parents to become U.S. residents so they can receive experimental medical treatment that could improve his chances of survival. You can read more about my efforts here: goo.gl/wvXYJ4
Live on Fox & Friends this morning to talk about my effort in Congress to get #CharlieGard to U.S. for medical treatment.

Earlier this week, my amendment to grant U.S. residence to Charlie Gard and his parents was unanimously approved by a congressional committee. Time is of the essence as this little boy fights for his life. I’m working with my colleagues in Congress on this letter to U.S. House leadership urging a full vote on this measure: goo.gl/EgpGW6
ICYMI: Thank you @FoxandFriends for the opportunity to share about my efforts in Congress to bring Charlie Gard to the U.S. so he can seek medical treatment: http://video.foxnews.com/v/5514100215001/

In his statement today, the president said he does not favor punishing children for the actions of their parents. I agree, and Congress must now act to treat DACA recipients with compassion. The president is not revoking DACA status immediately, but is giving Congress time to provide permanent relief for those who've been caught in legal limbo. A lasting solution can only be provided through the force of law, and President Obama created a difficult situation for everyone when he circumvented U.S. laws through Executive Order. I believe we can uphold national security, protect opportunities for American citizens, and provide assurances to DACA recipients in Southwest Washington who have done nothing wrong that we understand their plight and that they can build a future here in the only country that many of them have ever known.

As wildfires burn in Skamania County and other parts of Washington state, I know folks are having to evacuate their homes and businesses. I am praying for and standing ready to help those in harm’s way. Please contact my office if I can be of assistance: 360-695-6292. I also want to thank the firefighters who are working around the clock to combat the fires – our prayers are with you all as well.

I’m sending out a district update this evening about the work I’m doing in Southwest Washington. If you haven’t signed up to receive my e-newsletter, you can do so now @ https://herrerabeutler.house.gov/

Congressman Dave Reichert has led with honor. He’s been a protector throughout his career of serving the public in the military, as a cop, and as a member of Congress. I will miss serving alongside my friend and Washington state colleague when he retires at the end of this term, but his work to eradicate human trafficking, to honor and support law enforcement, promote public safety, and protect our environment will remain as his legacy. I wish him the very best in this next season of life along with his wife Julie and their grandchildren.

The U.S. House just passed my legislative amendment to prohibit any unfair Oregon tolling scheme on I-5 and I-205. I spoke on the floor of Congress tonight defending Southwest Washington commuters who were understandably concerned about a tolling proposal that would target their pocketbooks to fund Oregon's infrastructure projects. Working hard to protect Southwest Washington commuters’ hard-earned money! https://herrerabeutler.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398982

You can watch my opening remarks last night in support of my successful amendment prohibiting Oregon from imposing unfair tolls on I-5 and I-205. This amendment does not prevent Oregon or Washington from addressing the problems of the current I-5 bridge; it simply protects against Oregon’s skewed plans to make Washington commuters pay unfair tolls. Oregon’s current plan will treat Southwest Washington residents as a piggy bank while offering them little benefit. https://youtu.be/JKjHrETvwH4

Our country was forever altered 16 years ago. As we watched with horror the terrorist attacks on our home soil, we also witnessed the fortitude and heart of Americans displayed through the courage and compassion of our first responders, military, and the family members and friends of those who lost a loved one. We will never forget.

I was joined by nine Washington state legislators in sending a letter to Jay Inslee today urging the governor to take action against Oregon’s unfair tolling scheme. Many residents of Southwest Washington worry they’ll be disproportionately charged to pay for infrastructure project improvements well south of Portland, providing questionable benefit to them. You can read our letter here: goo.gl/KA9y8B

Firefighters face many health risks associated with their profession. I think of the firefighters on 9/11 who rushed into the smoke, flames, and debris – danger in its purest form – to save lives. We should do everything we can to mitigate the adverse health risks for our country’s firefighter heroes, which is why I am proud to have cosponsored the Firefighter Cancer Registry Act of 2017, which passed the House today. This bill requires the Centers for Disease Control & Prevention to develop and maintain a registry to collect data regarding the incidence of cancer in firefighters. This registry will allow researchers to have a greater understanding of the impacts smoke inhalation and other occupational hazards have on a firefighter’s health, and lead to better treatment options.

Newly-sworn in U.S. Forest Service Chief Tony Tooke visited the Pacific Northwest on Saturday to see firsthand the devastating effects of the Eagle Creek Fire in our beloved Columbia River Gorge. I am in full support of Chief Tooke’s call for passage of the Wildfire Disaster Funding Act, which I co-sponsored. Unless the agency can be freed from having to fire-borrow from their other budgets, including their forest management budgets, they will not be able to do the critically-needed forest treatments that will lessen the intensity of these ever-increasing mega fires. The health of our forests, communities and wildlife depend on it.

Here’s a good summary of the letter I sent with 9 Southwest Washington lawmakers to Gov. Inslee on Oregon’s tolling scheme: http://www.kptv.com/story/36352073/washington-lawmakers-oppose-plan-for-highway-tolls-in-oregon

Calling all Southwest Washington students! Pleased to host the Congressional App Challenge again this year for students in high school and below. You can register and get more info here: http://www.congressionalappchallenge.us/

We passed all 12 of our critical funding bills in the U.S. House this week: this is the right, most transparent way for Congress to do its job. As a member of the Appropriations Committee, we decide how much federal money every program receives.  Through this process, every single directly-elected U.S. Representative was able to thoroughly debate and amend spending for programs across every level of federal government. Included were Southwest Washington priorities like my amendment to defend Southwest Washington commuters from Oregon’s unfair tolling scheme. We also secured critical funding for wildfire prevention, military servicemen and women, and many others that will make life better here. You can read more here: https://herrerabeutler.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398987

Had a great time today with the Longview Pioneer Lions. Thank you for allowing me to brag on my kids a bit and also share some of our recent legislative wins for Southwest Washington like preserving salmon, preventing wildfires, and reducing veterans’ wait times to see a doctor.

I’m urging Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue and U.S. Forest Service Chief Tony Tooke to assist with the funding crisis in Skamania County and actively manage our forest resources. The latest funding crisis within our rural communities, as well as the wildfire devastation throughout the western United States, underscores the need for this agency to regain its focus. You can read the letter I sent to the administration today: goo.gl/x5gY26

I met with two small businesses in Clark County who are working to improve prescription drug safety. Combined, these two local businesses bring in $15 million to our region’s economy. Keep up the great work, GSL Solutions and ControlTek!

Many people don’t know what they can to do support a veteran in their life who’s going through a difficult time. September is Suicide Prevention Month and we can all #BeThere for our nation’s military heroes who are in crisis.   Text: 838255 to receive confidential support 24 hours a day/7 days a week Visit: VeteransCrisisLine.net  Call: 1-800-273-8255 and Press 1   Also, simple things like calling up an old friend, checking in on a neighbor, or inviting a colleague to go for a walk, are thoughtful ways to show someone you care. Our actions can help someone going through a tough time feel less alone. Our actions can also help save lives.

In partnership with the Veterans History Project, I’m inviting all Southwest Washington veterans to participate in an event on October 16 in Clark County to record their military stories to be preserved in the Library of Congress. The Nurse-Family Partnership (NFP) in Cowlitz and Clark counties has been a successful program for helping first time, low income mothers. I’m pleased to have supported a bill the U.S. House just passed that extends grant money to programs like NFP, who are working to help low-income mothers improve life for themselves and their children. Moms and babies who participate in programs like NFP have better health and educational outcomes and are better able to support themselves.    Of her experience in this program, one of the Clark County moms said: “NFP has been my rock for over two years. Being pregnant and then actually caring for a baby is hectic, scary and rewarding experience. There were times I felt everything was going wrong and I didn’t know what I was doing, but NFP always had my back! They are the calm after the storm and I always looked forward to my visits because they gave me peace and guidance.”

What a heartbreaking day for our country. I am grieving with those in Las Vegas in the wake of this senseless act of evil that has resulted in the devastating loss of innocent lives and has left so many with questions that can’t be answered. I commend the courage of the first responders on the scene, I am praying for strength for the families of the victims and healing for those who are wounded. May God be close to the brokenhearted.

I’m urging Senator Patty Murray and Senator Maria Cantwell to ensure my amendment to prohibit Oregon’s tolling scheme is upheld in the U.S. Senate's transportation funding bill. Lewis County veterans – I’m pleased to announce I’ll be adding a second veterans history event in Lewis County on October 16. I’m partnering with Veterans History Project to collect Southwest Washington veterans’ stories to be preserved in the Library of Congress. I will also be hosting the originally announced Vancouver-area veterans event the same day. For more details including how to sign up, please visit my website:  goo.gl/DH7p8D

Here in Washington state, Association Health Plans (AHPs) currently provide roughly 400,000 individuals with quality, affordable health care plans – and that’s despite these popular programs being undermined and restricted by our state’s Insurance Commissioner. For many years, I’ve worked in a bipartisan manner to strengthen AHPs because they are a critical solution to making good health care more attainable for more people. If implemented correctly, the President’s expansion of AHPs could help bring down costs of quality care for thousands of Washingtonians.   Unfortunately, supporting small businesses who want to provide health coverage for employees is one of the greatest areas of failure under the Affordable Care Act; the Obamacare small business exchange operated by Washington state only insures 164 people across all of Washington. There is no reason why small businesses shouldn’t be able to band together and offer employees the same types of quality health care plans as labor unions and large corporations do, and I will be eagerly monitoring how this executive order is implemented and will help however I can to make sure it is successful here in Southwest Washington.

It was a privilege to hear two dozen Southwest Washington veterans tell their military stories that will now be preserved in the Library of Congress as part of the Veterans History Project. We heard first-hand accounts of history, straight from the veterans who were on the frontlines. Thank you for serving our country!

I’m keeping a close eye on the large fire that broke out this morning at the Underwood Fruit & Warehouse Co. Praying for minimal loss for this business that is so vital to our region, that all those affected and battling the fire will stay safe during this time, and that power will be restored promptly to Klickitat County residents. I stand ready to help however I can.

For veterans in Pacific County, the VA Mobile Medical Unit will be in Raymond next week:    When: Monday, November 13 - Friday, November 17 November 13, 2017 – 9am-3:30pm November 14, 2017 – 8am-3:30pm November 15, 2017 – 8am-3:30pm November 16, 2017 – 8am-3:30pm November 17, 2017 – 8am-11:30am   Where: The American Legion 221 Duryea St Raymond, WA 98577     Services include:   • Primary health care appointments and walk-ups • Physical exams • Flu shots and other immunizations   • Prescriptions • Labs • Assistance in signing up for VA benefits   If you are a veteran who is already registered within the VA system, walk-up appointments will be available without appointment. If you are not in the VA system, you can get help with initial registration at the mobile medical unit.
Proud to vote for a pay raise for our military service members today, and permanently preserve giving an allowance to surviving military spouses.

Did you know that Oregon was convening its tolling advisory committee – tasked with working on Oregon’s plan to toll the I-5 and I-205 bridges – for a public meeting next Monday at 8:30am? I asked Oregon about what this committee can (and can’t) do to impact final tolling decisions, and what efforts they were taking to let Southwest Washington residents know about it. Read more here: goo.gl/jhuqup

The U.S. House’s tax cuts plan is a good deal for Southwest Washington taxpayers, and I will support it. A family of four in Southwest Washington making a median salary of $83,874 will get to keep $1,929 more of their money instead of paying it in taxes; and independent studies show 19,968 more jobs will be created in the state of Washington and middle-income families will see on average $2,672 more in their paychecks due to economic growth. You can read more about why I am supporting tax cuts here: goo.gl/rZvzC8

I proudly voted today to help middle-income Southwest Washington families keep almost $2,000 more of their money instead of paying it in taxes, and to boost their paychecks by $2,672 each year. To read more about why I supported tax cuts, click here: goo.gl/AWBipi

Oregon has confirmed that its I-5 and I-205 tolling advisory committee has “no statutory authority” over Oregon’s actual decision making on whether or how to toll those bridges. So, even if this advisory committee – with 3 Southwest Washington representatives and 17 Oregon representatives – decides that tolling both bridges is too harmful to Washington residents, Oregon has zero obligation to listen. I would like to be able to trust them when they say Southwest Washington residents won't be targeted to pay for infrastructure they don't use, but the bill the Oregon Legislature passed last year doesn't give me cause to do that. Read their response to my questions here: goo.gl/e9aocm
Due to the short, holiday week, we will not have mobile office hours in Lewis County tomorrow, Tuesday, Nov. 21. If you need assistance, please call our Vancouver office at 360-695-6292.

Thank you to the veterans who shared about their challenges with the VA at our roundtable over the weekend in Vancouver. We must address the mental health crisis our nation is facing. To do so, we need federal resources carefully targeted at efforts that will help thousands of people in Southwest Washington and across the country – families of loved ones facing mental health crisis, individuals addicted to opioids and fighting substance abuse disorders, and teens struggling with behavioral health issues and suicide. We can’t delay finding prevention and treatment solutions for folks in this vulnerable position. Today, I joined my colleagues in sending a letter urging the Administration to fund mental health and substance use programs: goo.gl/7bdzk2

It makes little sense for Southwest Washington to delay speaking up about tolls until tolling cameras are mounted over every lane of I-5 and I-205 and our money is in Oregon’s treasury. That’s why I’m urging Southwest Washington’s Regional Transportation Committee to weigh in on Oregon’s tolling plan at their committee meeting next week. You can read the letter I sent them here: goo.gl/oydZ6s

Kids deserve a voice at the table when it comes to health care. Thank you to the team at Children's National Medical Center for the excellent care you provide to our kids! It was an honor to celebrate with you last night and receive the Glass Bear Award. I will continue to fight to make sure every kid in Southwest Washington has their best shot at living a healthy, productive life. Some of my recent efforts include working to protect kids’ access to Medicaid, voting to extend Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP) for five years, and supporting the ACE Kids Act which would allow children of low-income families to cross state lines to receive the care they need.

Pausing to remember the attack on U.S. soil 76 years ago - and the many American lives lost that day. What a great happenstance that I was wearing “cranberry-red” for my meeting today with Malcolm and Ardelle McPhail from Long Beach. Thank you for sharing with me some of the latest issues facing Southwest Washington cranberry growers.

I applaud the International Trade Commission for voting to protect the U.S. softwood lumber industry and our timber jobs. You can read about Rep. Peter DeFazio and my bipartisan effort to bring much-needed relief to Oregon and Washington mills: goo.gl/W9bbfQ

We will have mobile office hours in Lewis County on Tuesday, Dec. 12 from 11:30am – 1:00pm. The next Lewis County mobile office will be Tuesday, January 9. Lewis County residents should call our Vancouver office at (360) 695-6292 for any assistance between December 13 - January 2.
I look forward to hearing from you during my live telephone town hall this evening from 5:30 – 6:30pm. You can join the event at any time by calling 1-877-229-8493 and using passcode 116365.

Fishermen, shellfish growers, and small vessel operators are key economic contributors to our Pacific County communities. I’m pleased to introduce a bipartisan bill extending protection for them from an overly-broad EPA rule. You can read more on this issue here: goo.gl/FkKezE

Terrible accident this morning as an Amtrak train derailed over I-5 near DuPont; praying for a quick recovery for the passengers injured and comfort for the families of those who lost a loved one. Washington State Patrol is tweeting updates here: https://twitter.com/wspd1pio

Today, we passed historic tax cuts where the average Southwest Washington family of four will get to keep $2,385 more of what they earn. Read why I supported lowering taxes for Southwest Washington residents here: goo.gl/XgBpGV

Craft breweries in Southwest Washington will save thousands of dollars annually with the passage of #TaxCutsandJobsAct. I am proud to have cosponsored the Craft Beverage Modernization and Tax Reform Act which reduces the federal excise tax brewers pay from $7 per 31-gallon barrel to $3.50.

Take a moment to watch and hear why I voted to allow the average Southwest Washington family of four to keep $2,385 more of what they earn – while protecting vital Social Security and Medicare lifelines.
Merry Christmas — I got this video from home while I am in DC and thought I should spread some holiday cheer from my daughter Abigail. :)
Boeing, the largest employer in our state, with many workers who live right here, is celebrating the passage of the historic tax cuts: goo.gl/xCt8KV

Today I supported extending funding for the Children’s Health Insurance Program so no state, including Washington, will run out of money to care for the nine million children who rely on CHIP funding. Read more about the bill the U.S. House just passed here: goo.gl/WWKAPB

Families shouldn’t have to live paycheck to paycheck because true economic recovery never arrived. A decade is too long to have stagnant wages and people stuck in low-paying or part-time jobs. Read the op-ed I wrote for The Columbian over the weekend: goo.gl/8TdB4r
